etymology.description: semantic 艹 (‘grass; plant’) + phonetic 化. Originally 𠌶 or 華 before the Han dynasty.
etymology.interpretation: 艹 signals a botanical meaning, pointing to flowers or plants. 化 contributes the sound, with historical readings aligning to huā, while earlier forms like 𠌶/華 show the same ‘flowering’ concept that later standardized as 花.

examples.chinese: 我买了一束花(我買了一束花)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎi le yī shù huā.
examples.english: I bought a bouquet of flowers.

examples.chinese: 他今天花了很多时间准备报告(他今天花了很多時間準備報告)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jīntiān huā le hěn duō shíjiān zhǔnbèi bàogào.
examples.english: He spent a lot of time today preparing the report.

examples.chinese: 这件衣服太花了(這件衣服太花了)，我不喜欢(我不喜歡)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn yīfu tài huā le, wǒ bù xǐhuan.
examples.english: This piece of clothing is too flowery; I don’t like it.
